title: Britain’s first acid killer doused mum just weeks before deadly attack on nurse
text:

Britain's first acid attack killer doused an innocent mother with a noxious substance just weeks before he killed a nurse with industrial strength fluid.

Xeneral Imiuu, 20, has been convicted of another acid attack after a jury heard he threw a corrosive substance over a mother who was "in the wrong place at the wrong time" at a cinema.

Imiuru, also known as Xeneral Webster, had previously been convicted of the manslaughter of nurse Joanne Rand, 47.

He had been aiming at another man when he doused the innocent mum head-to-toe in sulphuric acid while she was sitting on a park bench after visiting her daughter's grave in High Wycombe on June 3, 2017.

The family of Ms Rand have demanded to know why Imiuru was not caught after the earlier attack, and the police watchdog is investigating.

(Image: Thames Valley Police/PA)

Now he has been convicted over the earlier, similar incident March of the same year, when he also doused Neetta Vaidhya with acid in a West London cinema.

He is already serving 17 years behind bars over the death of Ms Rand.

A jury heard Imiura, also known as Xeneral Webster, had intended to hurl acid at another man when he threw the noxious substance at the west London Vue cinema on March 8 2017.

Instead it landed on Neetta Vaidhya, melting her sock and burning her feet, a jury heard.

(Image: PA)

She thought she had been hit by hot coffee when she first felt a burning sensation in her hands and feet until she saw her blue sock melting before her eyes.

Imiuru had been intending to hurl his acid at another man during an argument, in circumstances similar to the incident that just under three months would see him become Britain's first convicted acid killer.

On the afternoon of June 3 2017, Imiuru, then aged 19, had hurled acid during a tussle with another man which instead hit Ms Rand, a carer for people with dementia, who was sitting on a bench.

Ms Rand, 47, died of multiple organ failure after contracting septicaemia due to the burns.

Imiuru admitted manslaughter over the death of the mother-of-three following the incident.

(Image: BBC)

It has now emerged that Imiuru, now aged 20 years, could have been brought to justice following the earlier attack after he appeared in Oxford Crown Court today.

Imiuru had denied the acid attack, although he refused to leave his prison cell to attend the first day of his trial.

He has also now admitted offences including causing prison guard Paul Flower grievous bodily harm at a jail in Aylesbury, Buckhinghamshire, throwing urine at Bullingdon prison officer Yvette Wright and assault by beating of colleague Zena Rose by spitting at her.

Imiuru is to be sentenced for all of the crimes at a later date.

(Image: BBC)

Ms Rand's family said after he was jailed previously at Reading Crown Court: "Had this acid attack in March 2017 been investigated properly at the time, Webster the alleged perpetrator, would have been dealt with and may not have been free to carry out the horrific attack in June 3 2017 on Jo and she might still be with us."

Prosecuting in Imiuru's latest acid case, Lesley Bates told the jury at Oxford Crown Court: "Neetta Vaidhya was the unintended victim of an acid incident where the acid was thrown from one person towards another, intending to hit that other but it hit her by mistake - she was in the wrong place at the wrong time."

The Independent Office for Police Conduct is investigating whether a police officer probing the cinema incident should have released CCTV at an earlier stage.

The watchdog is investigating whether releasing the footage earlier could have helped bring Imiuru to justice before the incident which killed Ms Rand.
description: Xeneral Imiuru threw acid on an innocent cinema-goer just weeks before he threw acid that hit nurse Joanne Rand, eventually killing her, in High Wycombe
